```{r}
library(tidyverse)
```

```{r}
logs <- read_csv("https://www.thescoop.org/sports-data-files/footballlogs23.csv")
```

```{r}
head(logs)
```

```{r}
big10_runs <- logs |>
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |>
  arrange(desc(RushingAvg))
```

```{r}
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=big10_runs, aes(x=Date, y=RushingAvg, group=Team)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-4, 8))
```

```{r}
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=big10_runs, aes(x=Date, y=RushingAvg, group=Team)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-4, 8)) + 
  facet_wrap(~Team)
```

```{r}
big10_runs |> summarise(mean(RushingAvg))
```

```{r}
ggplot() + 
  geom_hline(yintercept=3.816, color="blue") + 
  geom_line(data=big10_runs, aes(x=Date, y=RushingAvg, group=Team)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-4, 8)) + 
  facet_wrap(~Team)
```
In conclusion, Maryland's rushing average has taken a sharp turn since Oct. 15 and looks like it's on a spiral since then. Maryland had a season high of 4 turnovers during the Penn State game. 

Looking at teams like Penn State and Michigan, they have maintained the Big Ten average.
